data.description:
Help us to build a <$400 PnP Ethereum full/archive/staking node based on ARM boads that uses only ~10 watts of power to run.

Ethereum on ARM provides a PnP Ubuntu server image for the Rock 5B, Odroid M1, Raspberry Pi 4 & Orange Pi  5 (soon) that run both Execution and Consensus clients as a Systemd service and automatically turns the device into a full Ethereum EL+CL node or a home staking box.

This is what we've been at these last months (thanks to your contributions): 

- Support and include more Ethereum clients. Current list: Geth, Erigon, Besu, Nethermind, Prysm, Nimbus, Teku and Lighthouse
- Testing and releasing an image for the Orange Pi 5
- Updating the documentation and translating to Spanish
- Research and include other blockchain components in the image: IPFS, Swarm & Status
- Release packages for running L2 nodes. Currently preparing a release and docs for: Optimism, Arbitrum, Polygon, Starknet and Gnosis.
- RISC V: Continue to research and try to run an node on this architecture. Working on VisionFive 2 board

Other info:

We are running a $365 Ethereum stake device with 3 validators using 10 watts  
			https://twitter.com/EthereumOnARM/status/1597889744821944320

Thanks for your donations and support. 

Our repository

https://github.com/diglos/ethereumonarm

Documentation page

https://ethereum-on-arm-documentation.readthedocs.io

Discord Channel

https://discord.gg/SCJW3cdC

Check our twitter account for updates

https://twitter.com/EthereumOnARM

Ethereum ...
data.title: Ethereum on ARM

data.description:
Join us in running a **$350 preconfigured Ethereum Full/Archive/Staking node** on ARM64 boards, consuming only 10 watts of power.

**Ethereum on ARM** provides a PnP Ubuntu Armbian image for the NanoPC-T6, Rock 5B, Orange Pi 5 Plus, and Orange Pi 5 that sets up and runs both Execution and Consensus clients as Systemd services. It **automatically turns the device into an ARM64 Full Ethereum node or a home Staking box**.

Our main goal is to **lower the barriers of running an Ethereum L1 or L2 node** by automating complex processes, ultimately encouraging more users to participate in the network. This contributes directly to **network decentralization**.

Additionally, our work empowers developers by providing them with the tools necessary to run a development or testing node and end-users to use their nodes for their daily operations.

This is what we've been up to in the last months (thanks to your past contributions):

- Develop **EOA-config**: A **console menu interface to easily run an L1 or L2 Full/Archive node in seconds** (currently in alpha).
- Support and include more Ethereum clients (added **Reth**). Current list: Geth, Erigon, Besu, Nethermind, Reth, Prysm, Nimbus, Teku, and Lighthouse.
- Testing and releasing images for several new devices: **NanoPC-T6, Orange Pi 5 Plus, and Orange Pi 5**.
- Testing and running an Archive node with Reth (currently running on a Rock 5B).
- **L2** support. We are supporting the following L2s: **Optimism (and Base), Arbitrum, Polygon, Starknet, and Gnosis**.
- Research on **Distributed Validator Technology**.
- Client diversity. We migrated our validators to **minority clients** to promote their adoption.
- Working with client teams for testing in ARM64 platforms (Reth and Nethermind).
- Working with **Dencun** Devops team for testing in ARM64 platforms.
- Working with Geth team for testing **Verkle tries migration** process in ARM64 platforms.
- **RISC V**: Continue to research and try to run a node on this architecture. Working on VisionFive 2 board.

Thanks for your donations and support.

**Our Repository**

[https://github.com/EOA-Blockchain-Labs/ethereumonarm/](https://github.com/EOA-Blockchain-Labs/ethereumonarm)

**Documentation Page**

[https://ethereum-on-arm-documentation.readthedocs.io](https://ethereum-on-arm-documentation.readthedocs.io)

**Discord Channel**

[http://discord.gg/ve2Z8fxz5N](http://discord.gg/ve2Z8fxz5N)

**Check our Twitter Account for Updates**

[https://twitter.com/EthereumOnARM](https://twitter.com/EthereumOnARM)

*Ethereum on ARM is an EOA Blockchain Labs, S.L. Spanish company project.*

GG18 - Ethereum Infrastructure
data.description: We participated in Gitcoin Round 18 (GG18). A heartfelt thanks to all our donors for their invaluable support.

data.name: Gitcoin
data.description: Gitcoin creates solutions that empower digitally native communities to fund, build, and protect what matters.

questions.query: Telegram Handle We Can Use To Contact You
Link to your Public Group Chat
Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile to prior rounds.
questions.explanation:
We’ve participated in the following rounds: Round 9, Round 10. Round 11, Round 12, Round 13, Round 14, Round 15, January 2023 Alpha round, Round 17, Round 18, Round 19, Round 20 and Round 22. 

Last rounds record: 

https://explorer.gitcoin.co/#/projects/0x9d84ffdf1483554511a0fa7d1dda1b2b1fa455fddb4733121a250a6d93a300f3

questions.query: How does your project contribute significantly to the Ethereum network's infrastructure? Please provide specific examples and metrics if available.
questions.explanation:
We provide the infrastructure needed for users to run Ethereum nodes (both L1 and L2) on single ARM64 boards. With our setup, users can run: 

- Full nodes 
- Archive nodes 
- Staking nodes 
- L2 nodes 
- Supernodes (L1+L2) on a single board 
- Obol DVT Cluster

questions.query: Describe any pioneering development work in your project, particularly in enhancing privacy, interoperability, or user experience.
questions.explanation:
We have successfully deployed the first ARM64 node running both Ethereum Layer 1 and Layer 2 nodes (which we call Supernode) running in the same device. In terms of operability, it combines L1 and L2 node capabilities on a single device enhancing the interaction between Ethereum’s different layers. 

We’ve achieved the first fully synced Geth node on a RISC-V board (Banana Pi F3), showing how Ethereum can run on open-source hardware, further enhancing decentralization. 

We successfully created a DVT Obol cluster in order to allow users to leverage this tecnology on ARM64 nodes.

questions.query: What specific problems or challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem does your project address? How does your solution improve upon existing alternatives?
questions.explanation:
Our project addresses several key challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem, specifically around decentralization, accessibility, and reliability 

By enabling Ethereum to run on commodity hardware it helps ensure that Ethereum can operate on a wide variety of devices, spreading control beyond large institutional stakers. 

We are integrating Distributed Validator Technology (DVT), which allows stakers to collaborate with other nodes to ensure their validators stay online. DVT improves fault tolerance and security reducing the risk of validators downtime. 

Our project provides a cost-effective, energy-efficient, and decentralized alternative to the expensive hardware typically required for running Ethereum nodes and staking. By lowering both the hardware and staking entry barriers (with Lido Community Staking node), and improving validator uptime, we will make Ethereum more accessible and resilient for individual stakers.

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation:
This is our 3-6 Month Roadmap: 
 

1. Lido Community Staking Module Deployment 

Objective: Enable staking with 2 ETH/stETH or less through the Lido Community Staking Module. 

Status: Ethereum on ARM Lido validators running on mainnet. WIP: Docs and Packages 

Impact: Lower the entry barrier for stakers, opening access to Ethereum staking for smaller participants and increasing decentralization. 


2. DVT Integration Obol Network 

Objective: Distributed Validator Technology (DVT) integration using Obol Network. 

Status: Mainnet . WIP: Documentation. 

Impact: Improve validator uptime and fault tolerance by allowing stakers to collaborate, ensuring validators remain online through nodes redundancy. 

See: 

https://x.com/EthereumOnARM/status/1897261587427418436 


3. RISC-V Development 

Objective: Continue RISC-V architecture development, focusing on expanding Ethereum node capabilities on open-source hardware platforms. 

Status: Waiting for a 16 GB RAM board and Consensus Layer clients cripto implementation for RISCV. 

Impact: Expanding hardware diversity within the ecosystem. 


4. Expanding L2 Support (Fuel Network) 

Objective: Add support for additional Layer 2 Fuel Network. 

Status: Mainnet already running 

Impact: Improve scalability by supporting more L2 solutions. 

5. Raspberry Pi 5 support 

Objective: Add support for Raspberry Pi 5 16 GB RAM 

Status: Completed. Looking for mature Ubuntu image and NVMe disk testing. 

Impact: Improve hardware diversity by supporting the most popular ARM64 Board. See: 

https://x.com/EthereumOnARM/status/1889297438101434374 

6. Infrastructure Maintenance 

Objective: Continuously maintain the existing infrastructure, including OS images and client updates. 

Thanks for your donations and support.

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the decentralization and security of the Ethereum network?
questions.explanation:
Ethereum on ARM maintains a low barrier for running a node by minimizing costs, energy consumption, and hardware requirements. By lowering these barriers, we ensure that both Ethereum L1 and L2 nodes can be operated by any user from home. This accessibility is important for enhancing the decentralization, security, and scalability of the Ethereum network.  

Without this reference, the hardware requirements and costs associated with running a node could increase, potentially restricting participation to only those with more resources. This would undermine the core principles of decentralization and inclusivity that are fundamental to the Ethereum ecosystem. By keeping node operation accessible and affordable, we help preserve Ethereum's resilience and long-term viability as a decentralized network.  

We provide the essential infrastructure for running a home validator, enabling anyone to become a home staker using low-powered and affordable hardware. In the coming weeks, we will support protocols that will allow staking with less than 32 ETH lowering even more the barrier to home staking. DVT technology is also available, ensuring home stakers can collaborate with other nodes to keep their validators online.  

We see our boards as the final frontier in commodity hardware. If Ethereum can run on these devices, which are affordable and energy-efficient, then we are in good shape for decentralization. If not, we may have a problem about running nodes on home hardware. 

The fact that 9 years after Ethereum release it is still possible running a full/archive/staking node on a 185$ board means that it is the most decentralized blockchain. One of our goals is to check and promote this kind of decentralization.

questions.query: For any project deploying smart contracts on blockchain networks, please list all your deployer addresses and their corresponding blockchain networks. Use this format for each entry: [deployer_address], [chain_id]—for example, 0x123abc..., 42161 (This represents a deployer address on the Arbitrum network). Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.

questions.query: How does your project contribute significantly to the Ethereum network's infrastructure? Please provide specific examples and metrics if available.
questions.explanation:
We provide the infrastructure needed for users to run Ethereum nodes (both L1 and L2) on single ARM64 boards. With our setup, users can run: 

Full nodes 

Archive nodes 

Staking nodes 

L2 nodes 

Supernodes (L1+L2) on a single board 

In the coming weeks, users will be able to leverage DVT technology to keep their validators online by collaborating with other stakers.

questions.query: Describe any pioneering development work in your project, particularly in enhancing privacy, interoperability, or user experience.
questions.explanation:
We have successfully deployed the first ARM64 node running both Ethereum Layer 1 and Layer 2 nodes (which we call Supernode) running in the same device. In terms of operability, it combines L1 and L2 node capabilities on a single device enhancing the interaction between Ethereum’s different layers. 

We’ve achieved the first fully synced Geth node on a RISC-V board (Banana Pi F3), showing how Ethereum can run on open-source hardware, further enhancing decentralization.

questions.query: What specific problems or challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem does your project address? How does your solution improve upon existing alternatives?
questions.explanation:
Our project addresses several key challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem, specifically around decentralization, accessibility, and reliability 

By enabling Ethereum to run on commodity hardware it helps ensure that Ethereum can operate on a wide variety of devices, spreading control beyond large institutional stakers. 

We are integrating Distributed Validator Technology (DVT), which allows stakers to collaborate with other nodes to ensure their validators stay online. DVT improves fault tolerance and security reducing the risk of validators downtime. 

Our project provides a cost-effective, energy-efficient, and decentralized alternative to the expensive hardware typically required for running Ethereum nodes and staking. By lowering both the hardware and staking entry barriers (with Lido Community Staking node), and improving validator uptime, we will make Ethereum more accessible and resilient for individual stakers.

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation:
This is our 3-6 Month Roadmap: 

1. Lido Community Staking Module Deployment 

Objective: Enable staking with 2 ETH/stETH or less through the Lido Community Staking Module. 
Status: Testnet already running. 
Impact: Lower the entry barrier for stakers, opening access to Ethereum staking for smaller participants and increasing decentralization. 

2. DVT Integration via SSV Network and Obol Network 

Objective: Distributed Validator Technology (DVT) integration using SSV Network and Obol Network. 
Status: Testnet already running. 
Impact: Improve validator uptime and fault tolerance by allowing stakers to collaborate, ensuring validators remain online through nodes redundancy. 

3. RISC-V Development 
Objective: Continue RISC-V architecture development, focusing on expanding Ethereum node capabilities on open-source hardware platforms. 
Status: Geth node sync achieved on a Banana Pi F3. 
Impact: Expanding hardware diversity within the ecosystem. 

4. Expanding L2 Support (Fuel Network) 
Objective: Add support for additional Layer 2 Fuel Network. 
Status: Testnet already running 
Impact: Improve scalability by supporting more L2 solutions. 

5. EOA-Config GUI Release 
Objective: Release an EOA-config GUI to simplify node setup and management for users. 
Status: Final testing. 
Impact: Improve the user experience, making it easier for home stakers and node operators to configure and manage their Ethereum nodes with a user-friendly interface.

6. Hardware Acquisition 
Objective: Acquire additional  ARM64/RISC-V boards and other hardware for ongoing development and testing. 

7. Infrastructure Maintenance 
Objective: Continuously maintain the existing infrastructure, including OS images and client updates. 

FUNDS 

Gitcoin Grant will be used to fund payroll expenses and to acquire additional hardware. These resources will enable the team to focus on key innovations and infrastructure improvements.
